comment info: Before seeing the graph, I had expected a pretty notable change between the rise of temperatures over the year, but was not expecting at all this drastic of an increase. When people in school or even out of school, used to bring up the topic of global warming, I honestly didn't think twice about it. I thought they were more of making guesses, or had very little evidence but I  was very wrong. If global warming keeps rising at this rapid rate, the outcome will soon be horrendous. We need to start taking action against this as we are huge contributors to the heat. Burning fossil fuels to generate energy is the main source of heat-trapping emissions, generating about two billion tons of CO2 per year. If we could just start by trying to use more and more different energy sources such as hydro electricity or wind power, then we would be able to notice a huge change in the temperature drop.

name: Simone Cronier
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
At first I thought that all the problems with global warming started in the 80s with the invention of the internet, but it seems that after reading the reveal that issues started years before. I now see that there are some areas on the graph that show positive anomaly values as early as the 1940s. This makes sense considering all the environmental movements in the 60s and 70s that advocated for problems like ozone depletion and global warming. I’m sure it would have surprised these protesters that the same problems they faced decades before are still happening today. 

I now look at the graph a different way. I knew that the red columns were bad, but I didn’t know just how bad they were. Since the black line in the middle of the anomaly values represents the global average temperature for 1951-1980 (56.66 degrees Fahrenheit), that means the global average temperature for the 2010s has gone up 33.8 degrees Fahrenheit! That’s insane! When the temperature continues rising, which it will, we could end up having no ice in the poles during the winter, 23% more people exposed to extreme heat, 61 million more people left without water, double the amount of some species losing their habitats, all coral reefs could die off, and small island nations could even submerge. And that’s only if the global average temperature increases by 1 degree Celsius! Mr. Yohe thinks the temperature could increase another 3.

name: Sean Hession
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Before the reveal, I did not understand how great the temperature rise was. I saw that there had been an increase and saw it as a sign of global warming. However, I did not fully comprehend how great of an increase 1 degree celsius was. After reading the article in the reveal, "Why Half a Degree of Global Warming is a Big Deal, I now understand why 1 celsius can make a huge difference. 
        An increase of 1 celsius might not even be something we would notice. We would sit in our air-conditioned houses ignoring the rising temperatures. However, many organisms in the world are temperature-sensitive. For example, to corals, a half a degree of celsius can mean their lives. Corals have photosynthetic that live on them, feed them, and give them color. However, if temperatures rise by as little as half a degree, these algae will leave the coral because they cannot stand the high temperatures. I learned that this is true for many other organisms as well. The reveal showed me how crucial it is to take action on climate change now, because if we do not reverse our actions soon, it could be too late.

name: Simone Cronier
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
“Is technology doing more harm than good?”

It’s clear to me from looking at this graph that the 80s haven’t exactly been easy on the global average temperature. I can see that as the years go by, the average temperature is moving up in increments of .25. This has already happened three times in the last 39 years and I wouldn’t be surprised if we hit the +1 degree Celsius mark in the next year or so. For anyone who doesn’t believe in global warming, this graph is a pretty clear sign that it’s real and started in the 80s with the invention of the internet. 

Even though the first Industrial Revolution had started before the graph’s x-axis’ shows, the fact that the columns were still in the blue zone after that and even through the second Industrial Revolution reveals just how bad our problem is today. We shouldn’t be having a higher increase in global temperature than what was happening during the Industrial Revolutions when factory regulation was limited. 

Looking at the world map, I can see that almost every single place on earth has experienced a recent increase in temperature. Sure it’s been almost a hundred years since the 50s, but the Arctic regions of the world shouldn’t have such significant temperature differences. Regions like Alaska and parts of Russia have had increases up to 3 degrees Celsius! We need to take a step back and decide if mass producing technology is the best for the earth in the long run.

replies.name: Y
replies.comment info:
@Simone Cronier It's not as cut and dry as it may seem.  Many other things have come around since the industrial revolution that create more problems for the earth than some factories and cars.  Air conditioning has pumped hundreds of tons of CFC's into the atmosphere, trucks and cars have spread to the developing world, usually older and produce more pollution than anything in the last 10 years has.  

The 1st world has really cleaned up its act in the last 30 years with emission regulations and environmental protection acts whereas other, more impoverished countries have not.  India and China have almost doubled their pollution in the past 20 years whereas the United States has reduced our emissions by almost 20 percent.  We don't need to step back and look at what we are doing, we need to look at what others are doing.  We are leading by example, but no one is following.

replies.name: S
replies.location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
replies.comment info:
@emma p 
The earth is definitely experiencing increases in temperature, but I wouldn’t say it’s because the earth is getting closer to the sun. Yes, there are times when the earth is closer to the sun since we’re moving on an elliptical path, but this process restarts every year, so there’s no way that being closer to the sun for some months in the year is going to make that big of an impact on global warming. Instead, I’d say the problem begins in the 1980s with the invention of personal computers, cell phones, and other technologies that would soon be mass produced. This process of mass producing leads to even more manufacturing which pumps a huge amount of air pollutants into the atmosphere every second. That’s just my take.

replies.name: K
replies.location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington NC
replies.comment info: @emma p While I definitely agree that global warming exists and is a problem, I don’t necessarily think that it is caused by the earth getting closer to the sun. As Simone said, the Earth is on an elliptical path and is closer to the sun at certain times of the year, but it cycles annually. I think that global warming problems began in the 1940s as technology and travel were drastically increased in a short period of time due to WWII. From the war to present day, mass productions as well as increased travel have increased pollutants in the atmosphere, which is a much more direct cause of global warming. Also, I love your title “One Climate, One World” because it embodies the fact that there is only one world and we need to work together to preserve it.

name: keandre

In today's age, most people either know or have heard of global warming. They know that the Earth is getting warmer but they don't know exactly the exact reason why. From 1880-1940 I expected the temperature to gradually increase at an even rate but it didn't. During that time, industrialization was just starting to appear but it seems that nature took its course. However, things changed in 1940 most likely because of World War II. After a period of switching between colder and warmer temperatures, the world started a trend of getting dramatically warmer. The highest peak of warming today almost triples the average temperature of the past. Because of the number of people and supplies we need to sustain ourselves, we are putting a strains on the Earth. Nowadays, people are starting to take notice of our actions because of the impacts they will have on our future. Even my friends at school are starting to protest. However, I still have many questions that I want to be answered. The last thing I wonder is since the average temperatures of today triple that of the past, how much warmer can it get before even more problems emerge?

comment info:
Two words pop into my head the second I see this graph. Global warming. Some say that preventive measures need to be taken to solve this problem and some don’t care to even acknowledge its existence, but either way, you can’t argue with statistics. 

I noticed that the average global temperature between 1880-1940 stayed below the midline. Industrialization had just begun. But, in 1940, the graph shows a spike in the average temperature for a couple of years. This makes me wonder how the effects of WWII (maximized industrial production, vehicle exhaust, bombs, etc.) could've caused the temperature to rise. Afterall, coal was still the world’s primary energy source which was essential to electricity, production and manufacturing, and transport. The graph shows that the temperature danced above and below the midline until just a couple years before 1980 (probably due to the industrialization of many other countries and the aftermath of WWII). Ever since 1980, the temperature has been constantly above the midline and is well on the rise with no sign of dropping again. 

I wonder if we'll ever really be able to slow the effects of global warming. We rely on fossil fuels in our day to day lives for transportation, heating, electricity, and for many other industrial applications. It isn’t like we can just stop using them. However, a gradual decrease of using fossil fuels and a gradual increase of using renewable energy should be something to think about as we go about the future.

name: Uma Volety

comment info:
Climbing Temperatures, No Way Down

Climate change is a very hot topic in today's day and age. Even with a pandemic going on outside, some of the most frequent news that I see is "Global temperature rises to decrease by 6% this year. Is that enough to reverse our climate crisis?" It's difficult to understand such a broad topic, but I found this graph very informative and interesting.

The first thing that I notice is that when this graph starts, in 1880, the temperatures weren't the coldest. In fact, it wasn't until about 23 years later that temperatures finally reached their all time low. Another thing that I notice is that between the years of 1935-1980, temperatures are, more or less, fluctuating along the centerline. I wonder if there are any patterns or reasons behind why the temperatures in this period fluctuated like they did. Something else that I notice is that after 1980, when temperatures started steadily increasing, they went up very quickly. Based on the numbers on the graph, temperatures have gone up almost .75 degrees from 1980. In only 40 years, our global temperature increased by much more than it ever has in the past, based on this graph. I wonder what practices we implemented to cause temperatures to go up so drastically, and if those practices are avoidable. Climate change has been a concern of mine for some time now, and I considered myself very knowledgeable on it, but this graph opened my eyes to what is really happening to our planet, and it's scary.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Uma Volety The "practices we implemented to cause temperatures to go up so drastically" are unfortunately things that are "necessities" in everyday life. The common answer of why temperatures are increasing so much is the greenhouse effect, which is caused by the immense amount of CO2 and other greenhouse gases we produce on a daily basis. My question for you is are we at a point of no return? Have we already passed that point? Global temperature rise is only decreasing by 6% this year and we are under intense quarantine, decreasing transportation pollution by a ton. Even though we are using practically the least greenhouse gases imaginable, the rate of temperature increase has barely changed. What more can we do before its too late, especially with the massive increase in temperature in the past decade?

name: Devyn D
comment info: From the top graph I noticed that there has been a positive trend in the average temperature since the 1980s, with the most significant increases since 2010. On the bottom graph I noticed that the poles have experienced the most significant increase in temperature with relatively stable increases everywhere else. I wonder why there are parts of the globe that have had decreases in temperature and why the changes are not universal. A possible title could be “It’s Getting Hot in Here.”

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Devyn D Temperatures may be rising in colder places because of a positive feedback loop regarding melting snow and increasing temperatures. As temperatures increase, snow melts and the land loses albedo, or the ability to reflect heat and light rather than absorb it. This means that temperature increases further because the land is absorbing more heat, and temperature increase means more snow melting. How can this chain be broken to stop the massive increase in temperature in the past decade?

comment info:
Headline: Rising Temperatures Linked to Growth of Industrialism
        I notice in the graph that global temperatures were over .25 degrees Celsius lower than average in many years from 1880 to 1930. Around 1940, temperatures saw a short spike above average. In the following years, readings fluctuated above and below average. Then, around 1978, temperatures skyrocketed, rising each year to almost 1 degree Celsius higher than average at current. These temperature changes are indicative of the presence of global warming and show the enormous effect modern industrialization has had. 
        In the 1880s until the 1940s, temperatures were lower than average almost every year. During this time, industrialization was beginning in many countries. Factories had begun spewing greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. The effect of these rapidly accumulating gases was not seen until temperatures began to fluctuate above and below average around 1940. Modern industrialization continued and gases like carbon dioxide and methane kept entering the air. As a result, temperatures started increasing steadily in 1980. Since then, every year has been above average temperature. New temperature records are now set often. Yet environmentally friendly growth has not happened. People continue to use the same devices that have caused this increase in temperature. I can only wonder if the world will ever decide to stop catastrophe by lowering greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Jeffery Austin
comment info: The late 1910's and 20's really starts the upward trend of global temperatures. This has to do with the start of mass market commercial industrialization in the United States and Europe. This is best exemplified in the "Roaring Twenties" when American consumers had enough money to buy many products off the factory line. The factories slowed in the thirties due to the Great Depression, but were back up in the 40's due to World War ll. But after that, the temperatures stagnated until the late 70's. And it coincides with the opening of a certain nation. China. Chinese exports really started in the 70's and 80's after the death of Mao Zedong. The aftermath in China led to a massive industrialization effort and a shift to authoritarian capitalism by successive leaders. The upward trend is due to the growing industry in China and India with very few regulations on the environment. This trend will probably continue as many third world countries also start to industrialize in a similar model.

I notice that this graph shows a dramatic increase in global average temperature since 1980, especially when compared to the average between 1880 and 1940. Obviously, the higher temperatures are depicted with orange and lie above the center line (zero) while  the colder temperatures are depicted in blue and lie below. I also see that over the past 5 years, the average temperature has remained above 0.75 degrees Celsius. In the map, we can see that a majority of areas across the globe are much hotter than they were in the mid 20th century. 

I wonder that why, even with tons of information similar to this, people continue to ignore the issue of a rising global temperature. I am curious about how this pandemic will affect this year's temperature -- Will the degrees Celsius drop because of reduced transit, the shutdown of smaller factories, etc.? Or, will it increase as a result of our greater dependence on home technology? I also wonder if the temperature spike in the 1940's was a result of wartime industrialization, or the weapons used in WWll. 

In these two graphs, we see temperatures rise primarily as a result of human action. I personally would title this graph "The Damage Which We Cause."

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Caroline Martin --

Thank you for your thoughtful noticings, wonderings, and headline.  
Please return Friday when we will share the link to the New York Times article that included this graph and map well as shout outs to some student headlines and the Stat Nuggets. You’ll also find an array of 140 heatmaps for the years 1880 to 2019 showing yearly temperature changes.   You will find how the data is collected and analyzed, as well as other reasons scientists give for global warming.

name: Laura Arbona
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
The first thing that I noticed when I looked at this graph was the contrast between the left and right side of it. The left side of the graph shows data that’s down in the negative values which, from the late 1800s to 2019, rises to high positive values seen on the right side of the graph. Another thing that I noticed were the different colors used. Anything below the x-axis of the graph is a light blue color while anything above it is an orange/red color. 

After studying the graph, I wonder why they chose to begin using data starting in the 1880s. Why not start before then? (After looking it up it seems as though the second Industrial Revolution began at around this time). I also wonder why there seem to be periods of time around the middle of the graph where the data jumps between being above or below the x-axis. 

All in all, the graph and map is showing the effects of Industrialization on global temperature as it has increased pretty consistently from the late 19th Century to the 21st Century. The map is also showing that places that are generally colder, such as the North and South Pole, are suffering more due to this drastic change in temperature. 

Was More Than One Industrial Revolution Really Necessary?
